question: Steve... Ah, I think we'd better have a talk. I've gotten-
answer: Your sister calls. I'll talk to you later.

question: Now, Steve! Let her wait.
answer: Okay, make it short and sweet.

question: Yeah, well... Listen... I... I don't think I'm going tomorrow.
answer: What! Come on, what are you talking about?

question: I don't know. I was thinking I might wait for a year... go to city--
answer: You chicken fink.

question: Wait, let me explain--
answer: You can't back out now! After all we went through to get accepted. We're finally getting out of this turkey town and now you want to crawl back into your cell--look, I gotta talk to Laurie. Now take it. We're leaving in the morning. Okay? You wanna end up like John? You can't stay seventeen forever.

question: I just want some time to think. What's the rush? I'll go next year.
answer: We'll talk later.

question: Not too good, huh?
answer: Why is it every girl that comes around here is ugly? Or has a boyfriend? Where is the dazzling beauty I've been searching for all my life?

question: I know what you mean. The pickin's are really gettin' slim. The whole strip is shrinking. Ah, you know, I remember about five years ago, take you a couple of hours and a tank full of gas just to make one circuit. It was really somethin.'
answer: Hey, John. Someone new in town.

question: Ahhh.
answer: You gonna go after him?

question: Hey, listen, Professor, if he can't find me, then he ain't worth racin', right?
answer: The big shot!

question: Where was I?
answer: Um, how you thought high school romances were goofy and we started going together just because you thought I was kinda cute and funny, but then you suddenly realized you were in love with me, it was serious... and ah... oh, you were leadin' up to somethin' kinda big.

question: You make it sound like I'm giving dictation. Well, seriously, what I meant was, that ah... since we do care for each other so much, and since we should really consider ourselves as adults. Now, I, ah... could I have a couple of those fries? Ah, where was I?
answer: ..."consider ourselves adults"...

question: Right... right... anyway, I thought maybe, before I leave, we could ah... agree that... that seeing other people while I'm away can't possibly hurt, you know?
answer: You mean dating other people?

question: I think it would strengthen our relationship. Then we'd know for sure that we're really in love. Not that there's any doubt.
answer: I think you're right. I mean, we're not kids anymore, and it's silly to think that when we're three thousand miles apart we shouldn't be able to see other people and go out.

question: Laurie, now, listen, I didn't ask for that back. I think that...
answer: I know. I just sort of think it's juvenile now. I'll keep it at home. It's less conspicuous there.

question: You don't want to wear it?
answer: I didn't say that. I understand and I'm not upset. I mean, I can't expect you to be a monk or something while you're away.

question: She's a little conceited--just playing hard to get.
answer: Listen, I came over here to talk to you about--

question: Any time, buddy. I'm your man. Nothing I like better than chewing the rug with a pal. You talk, I'll listen. I'm all ears. Shoot.
answer: Shut up.

question: Sure.
answer: Terry, I'm going to let you take care of my car while we're away--at least until Christmas. I'm afraid if I leave it with my-- What's wrong?

question: Yeah, well, go.
answer: Why don't you come with us?

question: Bullshit, man!
answer: Come on. For old time's sake.

question: What's the matter John? Did I say somethin' wrong? I'm sorry.
answer: Ah, man, it's nothin'.

question: Well, we'll see you later, okay?
answer: Right.

question: We'll all do somethin' together. You know, before Steve leaves.
answer: Okay, wait a minute. Now, you're not going?

question: Wolfman?
answer: Who is this?

question: This is Joe... in Little Rock, way down in the Valley.
answer: You callin' from Little Rock, California?

question: Long distance.
answer: My, my, my... listen, man, what kind of entertainment you got in that town?

question: Hey, Zudo.
answer: Hey, Milner.

question: Hey, man, what happened to your flathead?
answer: Huh?

question: What happened to your flathead?
answer: Ah, your mother!

question: What?
answer: Your mother. Hey, we been talkin' about you.

question: Yeah?
answer: Yeah. There's a very wicked '55 Chevy lookin' for you.

question: Yeah, I know.
answer: Watch out for the cop that's in Jerry's Cherry.

question: Here we go with another call out of the station. Can you dig it? Answer the phone, dummy.
answer: Pinkie's Pizza

question: Ah, yeah, listen, you got any more of those secret agent spy-scopes?
answer: Hit parade on the stethoscope?

question: No. No, the secret agent spy-scope, man. That pulls in the moon, the sky and the planets... and the satellites and the little bitty space men.
answer: You must have the wrong number, partner.

question: What? What? What?!!!
answer: We didn't say anything.

question: Quick! Hang a right!
answer: What? Why?

question: Cut over to G Street, I've just seen a vision! She was a goddess. You've got to catch her!
answer: I didn't see anything.

question: Hey, you're new around here. Where're you from?
answer: Turlock.

question: Turlock? You know a guy named Frank Bartlett?
answer: No. Does he go to Turlock High?

question: Well, he used to. He goes to J.C. now.
answer: Do you go to J.C.?

question: Yeah, sure.
answer: Oh, wow! Do you know Guy Phillips?

question: Yeah, sure. I got him in a class.
answer: He's so boss.

question: How would you like to ride around with me for awhile?
answer: I'm sorry, I can't. I'm going steady.

question: Ah, come on!
answer: I just can't.

question: Yeah, sure, Judy--her sister--her mother--anybody. I'll take 'em all. Listen, we'll go up and stop at that light. It'll turn red by the time we get there. All right? You ever get tired of going steady with somebody that ain't around--I'm up for grabs. So, you're Judy's little sister. Ah, shit,--how old are you?
answer: Old enough. How old are you?

question: I'm too old for you.
answer: You can't be that old.

question: Listen, listen. I think you better go back and sit with your sister. Hey, ah... where are they, anyway? They comin' back or somethin'? This is a joke, right? This better be a joke, 'cause I'm not drivin' you around.
answer: But you asked me. What's the matter? Am I too ugly? Judy doesn't want me with her and now you don't want me with you. Nobody wants me... even my mother and father hate me. Everybody hates me.

question: No they don't. I mean, I don't know, maybe they do. But I don't. It's just that you're a little young for me.
answer: I am not! If you throw me out I'll scream.

question: Oh, shit! Hey, get down! Hey, cool...
answer: Hey, is this what they call copping a feel?

question: NO! Uh uh. N-O. Don't even say that. Jesus...
answer: What's your name?

question: Hey, why are you so depressed? You'll forget him in a week. Listen, after you're elected senior queen you'll have so many boys after your bod--
answer: I don't want to go out with anybody else.

question: Laurie, I know it's a drag but you can't--remember what happened to Evelyn Chelnick? When Mike went to the Marines? She had a nervous breakdown and was acting so wacky she got run over by a bus.
answer: I just wish I could go with him or something.

question: What's that?
answer: What's what?

question: Hey, zit make-up! Wait till I tell--hey, everybody, Eddie--
answer: Come on, Steve--don't. Just cool it.

question: Let me see some of that stuff.
answer: You leave tomorrow? You and Laurie engaged yet?

question: No, but we got it worked out. We're still going together but we can date other people.
answer: And screw around--I hear college girls really give out.

question: Come on.
answer: Come on what?

question: Let's dance.
answer: No thanks.

question: Laurie, I want to dance.
answer: Who's stopping you?

question: Laurie, I thought since this was our last night together for 3 months, you might want to dance with me.
answer: How sentimental. You'll be back at Christmas.

question: I want to dance now, not at Christmas.
answer: Get your cooties off me-- Go ahead, slug me, scar my face. I wouldn't dance with you if you were the last guy left in this gym.

question: No, really, I'd like to, but I can't. I mean, if old Mr. Simpson came in here and saw me dancing with one of you sexy little--excuse me... one of you young ladies, he'd have my rear end. Hey, Warren. Come on, gentlemen, back inside. Put 'em out. Let's go.
answer: Kids... Want one?

question: All right. Hey, I thought you'd left.
answer: No, not yet. I have no matches.

question: Brother, how do I get stuck with dance supervision? Will you tell me that?... You going back East? Boy, I remember the day I went off. Got drunk as hell the night before. Just--
answer: Blotto.

question: Blotto. Exactly. Barfed on the train all the next day.
answer: Cute. Very cute. Where'd you go again?

question: Middlebury. Vermont. Got a scholarship.
answer: And only stayed a semester.

question: One semester. And after all that, I came back here.
answer: Why?

question: Decided I wasn't the competitive type. I don't know... maybe I was scared.
answer: Well, you know I might find I'm not the competitive type myself.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Well, I'm not really sure that I'm going.

question: Hey, now--don't be stupid. Go. Experience life. Have some fun, Curtis.
answer: Jane...

question: Anyway--good luck, Curtis.
answer: Yeah... I'll see you. Thanks a lot.

question: So the next night we found out where they parked and went out with ammunition.
answer: Don't you have homework or something to do?

question: No sweat--my mother does it. Anyway, he thought he was had. He started the car and couldn't see through the windshield--and zoomed straight into the canal--it was a riot. I still got some, so don't try anything.
answer: Hey, watch it will ya! Jesus Christ, thanks a lot. Hey, drivin' is a serious business. I ain't havin' no accidents because of you. Come on, don't give me any grief. I'm warning ya.

question: Spare me, killer. Why'd you do that?
answer: I don't like that surfing shit. Rock 'n Roll's been going downhill ever since Buddy Holly died.

question: Don't you think the Beach Boys are boss!
answer: You would, you grungy little twerp.

question: Grungy? You big weenie, if I had a boyfriend he'd pound you.
answer: Sure--ah, shit, Holstein!

question: Good, a cop--I'm going to tell him you tried to rape me.
answer: Oh, no--No. Hey--

question: It's past my curfew. I'm going to tell him how old I am, my parents don't know I'm out and you tried to rape me. Boy, are you up a creek.
answer: Hey--ah, really--don't say anything.

question: If you say "I was a dirty bird. Carol's not grungy, she's bitchin'." Say it--I'll tell him.
answer: I was a dirty bird, Carol's not grungy, she's bitchin.'

question: Where you going, Milner?
answer: I'm going home--sir.

question: Where you been, Milner?
answer: Ah--at the movies--sir.

question: Milner, you weren't around the 12th and G streets at about 8:30, were you?
answer: No, I wa at the movies--like I said-- sir.

question: Uh-huh. Milner, the reason I stopped you was because the light on your license plate is out. I'm gonna have to cite you for that. And Milner, the front end of this... this... this thing you're driving looks a little low.
answer: Oh, no sir. It's twelve and a half inches. Regulation size. Now, it's been checked several times. You can check it if you like, sir.

question: Look, Milner.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You can't fool with the law.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: We know that was you tonight. We have an excellent description of this car. I could run you in right now and I could make it stick. But I'm not gonna do that, Milner, you know why? Because I want to catch you in the act. And when I do, I'm gonna nail you, but good. Happy Birthday, Milner.
answer: Thank you--asshole.

question: Thank you--asshole.
answer: You're a regular J.D.

question: Here, file that under C.S. over there.
answer: C.S.? What's that stand for?

question: Chicken shit--that's what it is.
answer: Oh...

question: Hey, you know a guy around here with a piss yellow deuce coupe--supposed to be hot stuff?
answer: You mean John Milner? Hey, nobody can beat him, man. He's got the fastest--

question: I ain't nobody, dork. Right?
answer: Right...

question: Hey, you see this Milner, you tell him I'm lookin' for him, huh? Tell him I aim to blow his ass right off the road.
answer: What a babe... what a bitchin' babe... And Wolfman Baby, she's all mine. Okay, honey, here I come--James Dean lives! Stay cool, honey--don't let those creeps bug you. Wolfman, please don't let those creeps bug her... please. Hi! Hello... buenos noches? Need a lift? Nice night for a walk? Do you know John Milner? Curt Henderson? Sure you wouldn't like a ride somewhere? Did anyone ever tell you that you look just like Connie Stevens? You do! I mean it! Just like Connie Stevens. I met her once.

question: What a babe... what a bitchin' babe... And Wolfman Baby, she's all mine. Okay, honey, here I come--James Dean lives! Stay cool, honey--don't let those creeps bug you. Wolfman, please don't let those creeps bug her... please. Hi! Hello... buenos noches? Need a lift? Nice night for a walk? Do you know John Milner? Curt Henderson? Sure you wouldn't like a ride somewhere? Did anyone ever tell you that you look just like Connie Stevens? You do! I mean it! Just like Connie Stevens. I met her once.
answer: For real?

question: Yeah. At a Dick Clark road show.
answer: You really think I look like her?

question: No shit--excuse me, I mean I'm not just feeding you a line. You look like Connie Stevens. What's your name?
answer: Debbie. I always though I looked like Sandra Dee.

question: Oh yeah--well, you look a lot like her too.
answer: This your car?

question: Yeah. I'm Terry the--they call me Terry the Tiger.
answer: It's really tough looking.

question: What school do you go to?
answer: Dewey--can it lay rubber?

question: Oh yeah, it's got a 327 Chevy mill with six Strombergs.
answer: Wow--bitchin' tuck and roll. I just love the feel of tuck and roll upholstery.

question: You do?
answer: Yeah.

question: Well, come on in--I'll let you feel it. I mean, you can touch it if you want-- I mean the upholstery, you know.
answer: Okay. Peel out.

question: What?
answer: Peel out. I love it when guys peel out.

question: What's wrong with you! You're acting like a snotty--
answer: Oh God, come on.

question: Come on what?
answer: Oh, Steven--please, everybody's watching. Smile or something. You think I care if you go off. You think I'm going to crack up or something. Are you conceited!

question: Quit--quit pinching--I don't know why I ever started taking you out in the first place.
answer: You take me out? When we first met you didn't have enough sense to take the garbage out... I asked you out, remember?

question: What do you mean, you asked me out!
answer: Backwards Day--remember? If I had waited for you to ask me--even after that you didn't call me for two weeks.

question: I was busy.
answer: You were scared. Dave Oboler told me. Then when you did ask me out you didn't kiss me for three dates.

question: Well--I was--
answer: Scared--Jim Kaylor told me. I even asked my father why you hadn't kissed me.

question: Your father--great!
answer: He said he thought you were bright and you'd probably think of kissing me after a while. You didn't, of course. I had to. Remember that picnic?

question: Out at the canyon?
answer: Oh boy! You can't remember anything-- the first one, up at the lake. That was the first time you kissed me--I practically had to throw myself at you.

question: I remember. What's wrong?
answer: Go to hell.

question: What are you doin', stealing hub caps?
answer: Well--hey, Wendy.

question: How've you been?
answer: Fine. Great. How've you been?

question: I'm coming--wait a sec. She's got her car. Hey, I thought you were going away to school.
answer: Ah, maybe... maybe.

question: Same old Curt. All the time we were going together you never knew what you were doing... well, anyway, I gotta go.
answer: Hey, Wendy--where are you going?

question: Nowhere.
answer: Well, you mind if I come along?

question: Okay.
answer: Okay.

question: I go to Dewey too, ya know.
answer: I never seen ya.

question: I bug out a lot. When I graduate, I'm going to join the Marines.
answer: They got the best uniforms. But what if there's a war?

question: With the bomb, who's going to start it? We'd all blow up together. Anyway, I'd rather be at the front. I'm like that--rather be where the action is, you know. Once I got in a fight with--
answer: I love Eddie Burns.

question: Eddie Burns--oh, yeah, Eddie Burns. I met him once, too.
answer: You really think I look like Connie Stevens? I like her--Tuesday Weld is too much of a beatnik, don't you think?

question: Yeah, beatniks are losers.
answer: Who do you like? I mean, singers and stuff.

question: Ah hell--I like most of the people you like.
answer: That's nice--we got a lot in common. You know what I'd like more than anything in the world right now? I'd love a double Chubby Chuck. Isn't that what you'd like more than anything right now?

question: Hey, Deb. How's my soft baby?
answer: Beat it, Vic. I'm not your baby.

question: Oh, come on, honey. So I never called you back. I've been, you know, busy...
answer: Three weeks... besides, it only took one night for me to realize that if brains were dynamite, you couldn't blow your nose.

question: Look who's talking. Who's the wimp you're hanging out with now? Einstein?
answer: Tiger happens to be very intelligent. Unlike you. I know every thing your dirty little mind is thinking... ...it shows...

question: I won't be home.
answer: You seem to, ah--know a lot of weird guys.

question: That sex fiend is not a friend of mine; he's just horny. That's why I like you, you're different.
answer: I am? You really think I'm intelligent?

question: Yeah. And I'll bet you're smart enough to get us some brew.
answer: Brew?

question: Yeah.
answer: Brew... oh--yeah... oh, sure... Yes! Liquor! This place is too crowded anyway.

question: I don't know, but I'm going to find out.
answer: I know her!

question: Okay, come on, who is she?
answer: You know Mr. Beeman? He owns Hepcat Jewelers.

question: Yeah.
answer: Well, she's his wife.

question: But she was young and beautiful, and cruising 10th Street. You're thinking of someone else.
answer: Mr. Beeman's not so old.

question: What cruel fate keeps me from my true love? How am I ever going to meet her?
answer: Did you know that my ex is going to become a presidential aide? It's supposed to be a secret, but his big ambition in life is to shake hands with President Kennedy. How are you going to accomplish that at J.C.?

question: Maybe I've grown up. Maybe I've changed my mind.
answer: Maybe you don't think you can do it!

question: Maybe you should shut up!
answer: Maybe I will... and maybe I won't.

question: Maybe.
answer: Look, there's Kip Pullman! He's so neat. Do you know Kip?

question: Huh? Yeah, I know him.
answer: Talk to him when we go by.

question: What do you want me to say?
answer: Anything... I just want to meet him.

question: Kip, baby, what's up? Not much, just wanted to let you know that Bobbie here is hopelessly in love with you and trembles at the sight of your rippling biceps...
answer: You creep, fink, son-of-a-bitch--

question: Help, wait! Joke--Joke--Bobbie, remember your nose bleeds!
answer: Get out--get out of my car--I hate you!

question: One ten cent coke. Is ice extra? All right, ice.
answer: Thanks for nothing. Oh rats, I though some of my friends might be here.

question: Probably a couple of weeks past their bedtime.
answer: Wait, there's Dee Dee. I hope she sees me.

question: Oh Shit, Dee Dee! Have to be before noon. No. Hi--ahh, this is my, ahh, cousin, Carol. I'm kinda babysitting tonight.
answer: Babysitting!!

question: Jesus--watch it, will yuh? Been hittin' me all night. Kids will be kids, you know. Watch out--damn it! Look what--why don't you grow up! We don't get along too well. It's been like this--
answer: You spastic creep!

question: We don't get along too well. You know what cousins are like.
answer: Hi cousin, how's your bod?

question: Old Harper, rrright! He gives her an OK sign with his fingers and goes over to the store. He starts to enter, then stops and thinks. He sees a man in a business suit approaching, and smiles. Excuse me, sir, while you're in there-- I mean, since you're going in anyway, I wonder if--
answer: Yes, son?

question: Could you--sir--could you give me the time?
answer: Why sure, it's a quarter to twelve.

question: Great. Quarter to twelve. Thanks a lot. Pardon me, sir, but I lost my I.D. in--in a flood and I'd like to get some Old Harper, hard stuff. Would you mind buying a bottle for me? Thanks, here's enough for a pint. Hi. Still quarter to twelve.
answer: Right-o. Night.

question: Night. Hey, no. Not wine. Ssss--hey! Hi there--ah, say--was there an old man in here a minute ago? Yeah--ah--let me have a Three Musketeers, ah, and a ball point pen ther, a comp, a pint of Old Harper, couple of flashlight batteries and some of this beef jerky. A what? Oh, sure-- Oh nuts, I left it--I left it in the car. Well, I can't. I also ah, forgot the car.
answer: Hey, did ya get it? Ya get it, ya get it? You got it. You got it! You didn't get it. Why didn't you get it?

question: Ah, well, I needed some things and I thought as long as I was in there-- look, Debbie, can you loan me a dollar?
answer: What? Are you for real? Come on. Girls don't pay. Guys pay.

question: Yeah, well, see--I've only got a fifty and he doesn't have change.
answer: Well, I can't believe this... I really cannot believe this. Here.

question: That's Freddy Benson's Vette... he got his head on with some drunk. Never had a chance. Damn good driver, too. What a waste when somebody gets it and it ain't even their fault.
answer: Needs a paint job, that's for sure.

question: That Vette over there. Walt Hawkins, a real ding-a-ling. Wrapped it around a fig tree out on Mesa Vista with five kids in it. Draggin' with five kids in the car, how dumb can you get? All the ding-a-lings get it sooner or later. Maybe that's why they invented cars. To get rid of the ding-a-lings. Tough when they take someone with them.
answer: You never had a wreck though--you told me.

question: I come pretty close a couple of times. Almost rolled once. So far I've been quick enough to stay out of here. The quick and the dead.
answer: I bet you're the fastest.

question: I've never been beaten--lot of punks have tried. See that '41 Ford there? Used to be the fastest wheels in the valley. I never got a chance to race old Earl. He got his in '55 in the hairiest crash ever happened around here. He was racing a '54 Chevy, bored and loaded, out on the old Oakdale Highway and every damn kid in town was out there. The Chevy lost its front wheel doing about 85. The idiot had torched the spindles to lower the front end and it snapped right off. He slammed bam into the Ford and then they both of them crashed into a row of cars and all those kids watchin! Jesus, eight kids killed including both drivers, looked like a battlefield. Board of Education was so impressed they filmed it. Show it now in Drivers Education, maybe you'll see it. Anyway, since then street racing's gone underground. No spectators, I mean. Too bad.
answer: I'd love to see you race.

question: Come on! None of that.
answer: Whadaya mean? I'm the one who's supposed to say that. Whadaya afraid of? I'll keep it above the waist.

question: Funny... Who knows, in a few years--but not now, bunny rabbit.
answer: Bunny rabbit! Oh brother, you are such a drip.

question: Come on, open the door.
answer: If you say "Carol's not a bunny, she's a foxy little tail."

question: Carol's not a rabbit, she's a foxy little tail.
answer: You say the cutest things.

question: Whadaya doin', creep?
answer: Me?

question: No, I'm talking to the other fifty creeps here. You know Gil Gonzales?
answer: Gil Gonzales... no.

question: Don't know Gil... you oughta. You really should.
answer: Yeah... why?

question: No reason... he's a friend of ours... and that's his car you're sitting on. Hey, where ya goin?
answer: No place. Not going any place.

question: Ya must be going someplace--I mean ya left here. Bring him over here, Ants, I want to show him something. Here--bend down, look here. See that? Right across there--see?
answer: I guess so--yeah.

question: You scratched it, man. Where do you get off sitting on Gil's car, huh, man?
answer: I'm sorry. It's not much of a scratch. I don't think he'll even--

question: That's funny Hey, you guys know Toby Juarez? He's a Pharoah, isn't he?
answer: Toby Juarez. Yeah, sure we know Toby.

question: He's a friend of mine.
answer: Sure, good old Toby. He's a friend of yours. That's cool... we all hate his guts.

question: Oh--well, I don't know him that much anyway.
answer: We killed him last night.

question: Shotgun!
answer: No, I called it!

question: When?
answer: Before we picked you up.

question: Who is this on the Wolfman telephone?
answer: Hello, Collect...

question: Pardon me. Your name is Colette?
answer: Yes. Collect Call.

question: Your name is Colette Call?
answer: Sir, this is the Operator.

question: Are you French, Operator?
answer: This is a collect call for Wolfman Jack.

question: I... I love you, Operator.
answer: Is this Wolfman Jack?

question: Is Floyd there?
answer: It's for a Wolfman... Jack...

question: Tootie fruiti all ruti... It's Super Cola! It's a... a little... strong, I think.
answer: It's the living end.

question: Yeaah, I guess it wasn't mixed.
answer: Wow, it's pretty tonight. It's a perfect night to go horseback riding-- I was going with a guy once who had a horse.

question: Oh yeah? I used to have a couple of horses myself.
answer: Really?

question: I used them for hunting. I do a lot of hunting. Deer mostly, although I got a couple of bear last year. Yep, they were good ponies--hunting ponies. I had to train 'em special, you know.
answer: Do you still have 'em? We could go for a ride.

question: No, I had to sell 'em. To get these wheels... and a jeep. I also have a jeep pick-up, with four-wheel drive. It's got a gun rack. And I use that for hunting mostly.
answer: Why do you kill little animals? I think that's terrible.

question: Oh, well, yeah, I figure with bears, though, it's either me or them... You know, I think you're really neat.
answer: Wait a second.

question: Oh, jeez, I'm sorry. I don't know what got into me--I didn't mean to-- maybe it's the booze or something.
answer: There--now. Ow--you pinched me.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Let me get my head over here--okay, now you get up--

question: Ow--my leg, my leg. Ow, watch it!
answer: Ummm, I just love tuck 'n roll upholstery.

question: Geez, it's like Grand Central Station around here. Why don't we go someplace else.
answer: Nah, come on. They won't come back.

question: Wait a minute. I got a blanket in the back. Why don't we go over into the field?
answer: All right. Okay.

question: Hello.
answer: Yeah!

question: How old are you?
answer: I'm thirteen, how old are you?

question: I'm only fourteen.
answer: Oh, boy, I love you, Wolfman.

question: Hey, terrific, I love miniature golf.
answer: I hate it.

question: Well, I don't play that often really. Ah--what're we doing here then?
answer: We're outta gas.

question: They don't sell gas here.
answer: No... but we're outta money, too. Come on, Carl.

question: Curt.
answer: All right, men.

question: What're you punks doing?
answer: Hey, hi. Mr. Gordon, what's up?

question: Henderson--Curt Henderson? You with these punks?
answer: These are my friends. We were just...

question: Jeez, you guys had me scared. Hey, you haven't left yet?
answer: Oh ah--no--no, I'm not-- I mean, I'm not leaving until tomorrow.

question: You know, it doesn't make sense to leave home to look for a home, to give up a life to find a new life, to say goodbye to friends you love just to find new friends.
answer: What? Say that again, I didn't--

question: That's what Curt said.
answer: Oh, figures. You must've talked his ear off trying to get him to stay.

question: That's not true. I didn't say anything. Curt just said at dinner tonight he realized there was no big hurry. He thought he should take it easy for a while, go to J.C. and try to figure out what he wants to do with his life.
answer: That sounds logical.

question: You think so?
answer: Sure. I think Curt's probably right for Curt. Not for me though. Laurie, look at me. Now you know what I want out of life. And it's just not in this town.

question: I'm not going to the airport tomorrow. Steve! Don't.
answer: It's our last night together for three months... come on.

question: We've been through this before.
answer: I'm going to miss you so much. I need something to remember you by. You don't want me to forget you.

question: No...
answer: What's wrong? You're just lying there.

question: Well go ahead, you want to.
answer: Not like that.

question: If you're not going to remember me for anything else, why don't you go ahead?
answer: You want it and you know it. Don't be so damn self-righteous with me. After those things you told me about watching your brother--

question: You're disgusting! Get out of my car! I told you never--
answer: I'm sorry.

question: Anyway, the Goat Killer--
answer: Let's talk about something else.

question: --Whenever he strikes, he leaves a bloody goat's head near the victim. Isn't that creepy? They thought he went up to Stockton, but two nights ago they found Carlie Johnson and Don White right here by the canal all hacked to pieces and--
answer: Who do you think'll take the regionals this--

question: --not only were there bloody goats' heads, but he had switched all the parts of their bodies around. You know putting her arms on him and his legs on--
answer: Wait a second. Did you hear...?

question: You think it's the Goat Killer?
answer: No! I mean, no. Listen, I'll go for help, you stay here.

question: Come on, we'll hide in the field. Maybe if it's the Goat Killer he'll get somebody and we'll see the whole thing.
answer: I don't want to see the whole thing. Especially if it's us he--oh, why me? I'm going to look lousy with your legs and a goat's head and--

question: Shhh--he's stopped. I can't see him very--I think he's coming this way.
answer: Well, as long as he's not--Debbie! Debbie!

question: Well, as long as he's not--Debbie! Debbie!
answer: Terry!

question: Who, me? Why me?
answer: Terry.

question: It doesn't look like a gear shift knob.
answer: Come on, will ya? Give it back to me.

question: Well, go ahead, cream me. What's wrong, you're a tough guy. Break my arm, see if I care.
answer: Forget it.

question: I was just going to keep it for a little while. You're an ogre, just like my father. He won't let me play records, or stay out late, or anything.
answer: He ah--doesn't like you to stay out late?

question: No--he's terrible. Once I was at a party that didn't end till late and he called the cops. Can you imagine? It was only a little after midnight and he had the whole police force--
answer: Say, where do you live anyway?

question: Over on Ramona, why? Oh no. Uh uh. You thought I'd tell you where--not me, not old Carol. The night is young and I'm not hitting the rack until I get a little action. What do you keep lookin' at? Who's that? You know him? He's following awful close.
answer: Grab onto something.

question: Grab onto something.
answer: Sorry if I scared ya, man.

question: Takes more than that to scare me.
answer: Where ya been hiding? Didn't anyone tell ya I been looking for ya?

question: Hey, I can't keep tracka all the punks lookin' for me.
answer: They say you're the fastest thing in the Valley. But that can't be your car, man. That must be your mama's car. Hell, I feel embarrassed just getting near ya.

question: Ya should, man--you're driving a field car.
answer: Field car? What's a Field Car?

question: Field Cars drive through the fields, dropping cow shit all over the place to make the lettuce grow.
answer: That's pretty good. Hey, I like that paint job you got. What they call that--sorta a cross between Piss Yellow and Puke Green, ain't it?

question: Yeah, well, you're car's so ugly you must have to sneak up on the pumps to get a tank of gas.
answer: Well, at least I don't have to move over to let a funeral go by, man.

question: Hey--any of you guys know a blonde in a white T-Bird?
answer: Yeah, I seen her, what about it?

question: I was just wondering who she is.
answer: She's outta your price range, man. My brother's been with her and he clued me in.

question: Price range? You mean she's a--
answer: Yeah, Thirty Dollar Sheri. Can you believe that? Thirty dollars.

question: Fuzz ahead, watch it.
answer: Where?

question: Fuzz ahead, watch it.
answer: Where?

question: I think I'm gonna go over to Burger City.
answer: Yeah. Yeah. Laurie's probably over there.

question: You really think she's got me worried about where she is, don't you?
answer: Well...

question: No.
answer: Make up your minds.

question: No, thanks. U'mm. You know we got to report the car missing.
answer: All right. See yuh.

question: Listen, ah--Carl, I--
answer: Curt.

question: Curt. Despite you scratching Gil's car, I like you. And I know what you'd like more than anything right now. Like every guy in town, you got the same secret dream, right? Ya want to join the Pharoahs. Huh? You can admit it--you'd like to--but you never dreamed it could be possible, did you? Well, tonight, I'm goin' to give you your chance. Get down! Okay. Now you got it? I'm stayin' here. You're on your own.
answer: Wait a minute, wait a minute, Joe. What if he hears me?

question: Shhh. Listen. Look at it this way
answer: No.

question: Two, you foul up and Holstein hears you and well, ah... you don't want that, right?
answer: No, I don't.

question: Three, you are successful and you join the Pharoahs with a carcoat, and the blood initiation and all that, huh?
answer: Wait--wait a minute. Wait a minute! What blood initiation?

question: Why are we stopping here?
answer: Carol...

question: What?
answer: I--I don't think that I can control myself any longer.

question: You can't?
answer: No... Carol, I've got to have you.

question: Me?
answer: All night you've been sitting there and you've been so sexy and it's been so hot--and I can't wait any more...

question: Well--well, a lot of that's an act, you know. Like... like my crying. It was just an act.
answer: Well, it's been building up inside of me like a volcano, all night. Maybe if I knew where you lived I could fight it--I could take you home--but since you won't tell me, and since here we are--I've got to have you. It's too late--

question: It's not too late! It's never too late! 231 Ramona--two three one--
answer: Two three one--

question: Hi. You mind if I sit down?
answer: Hi Budda. No, have a seat.

question: I got five minutes outa the rat race, and I saw you all alone. For a change. Where's Laurie?
answer: I don't know.

question: I thought the two of you'd be going strong, this being your last night and everything--
answer: We broke up. No big deal.

question: Wow... what happened?
answer: Nothing. We were out at the canal and... we had a fight. What's so funny?

question: Nothing. Just thinking. A girl like Laurie--I mean, she goes to school and is cute and popular and all, but we're not so different. We know what we want. I've seen her after you for two years now.
answer: She's not like that.

question: All right, relax... old fart. Listen, I'm off in an hour. If you wanta come over, my girlfriend's away for the weekend.
answer: I don't know...

question: Why don't you? I never got a chance to talk to you. You're leaving tomorrow. Listen, I gave up a long time ago, so it'd be just for fun. No problems. I'll see ya later then.
answer: Budda, Budda wait. I gotta get up early and--I just don't think it'd work out.

question: She's got you so brainwashed--well, hell. Some day I'm gonna win. Don't ya think?
answer: Sure.

question: Oh boy, I'll tell you something, that car must've jumped five feet in the air! You sure you got to go? The night's young.
answer: Yeah, there's some things I got to do. I still want to find that blonde.

question: I think she was an optical delusion, man. Psychology-wise it ain't good to dwell on it. You'll alter your ego or something. Anyway, catch ya tomorrow night?
answer: Yeah, I guess so.

question: Guess so? Man, we don't admit a lot of guys to the Pharoahs. You understand we're going to have to swipe your jacket and all--you gotta make up your mind.
answer: Hey--I'll see you guys.

question: My, my, my. You only got five minutes left, if you want to talk to the Wolfman. Gonna make all your dreams come true, baby.
answer: Wolfman...

question: Yeah.
answer: Would you dedicate a record to keep me and my girlfriend together?

question: Are you separated?
answer: Well, see, we're havin' a little problem.

question: This the first time you've been quiet all night.
answer: I had fun. Goodbye. Do you like me?

question: Yeah. I like you. You're all right.
answer: But I mean, do you like me?

question: I, ah... I like you. Okay?
answer: Couldn't I have something to remember you by?

question: 'Bye, kid.
answer: Gee, thanks. It's just like a ring or something.

question: Yeah.
answer: It's like we were going steady. Wait'll I tell Marcia.

question: Wait a minute, now.
answer: Wait'll I tell everybody.

question: Don't go overboard with this thing.
answer: Well, I'll see you around.

question: Hold that up.
answer: I've been thinking--maybe you're right. Why should I leave home to find a new home. Why should I leave friends that I love to find new friends?

question: Wait a minute, wait a minute. I've heard this already. Aren't you the one who for eight weeks has been telling me you have to leave the nest sometime?
answer: I realize that. I realize--

question: No--no realizing. You've been telling me all summer that it's time to pull your head out of the sand and take a look at the big, beautiful world out there. Gimme this thing.
answer: I don't know--I--

question: I feel like a mid-wife.
answer: I guess I was wrong. I may have been wrong.

question: Wrong nothing. You've been talking about getting out of this town for eight weeks. And now--goddamnit!-- you're just--you're just mentally playing with yourself. If you can just relax, we'll talk about it at the airport.
answer: Where are you going? It's awfully early in the morning.

question: I have a dental appointment.
answer: Come on, Curt...

question: Hi, Karen, Judy. Oh yeah. So what? I wouldn't know.
answer: Help... I mean, I want two cherry cokes with lots of ice. Never mind, forget the cokes, just bring the ice, pronto.

question: Out! OUT!
answer: What??

question: I need the car--now.
answer: What's going on?

question: I don't believe it! You practically get killed trying to get your car back, then you let him have it.
answer: It's not my car.

question: What?
answer: What? IT IS NOT MY CAR!

question: Well, where is your car?
answer: I DON'T HAVE A CAR!

question: You know, I had a pretty good time tonight.
answer: Oh come on, you're just--

question: No, no, really. I really had a good time. I mean, you picked me up and we got some hard stuff and saw a hold-up, and then we went to the Canal, you got your car stolen, and then I got to watch you gettin' sick, and then you got in this really bitchin' fight... I really had a good time.
answer: You think so? Yeah--well I guess I have pretty much fun every night.

question: Anyway if you're not doing anything tomorrow night, why don't you come over?
answer: Yeah--well, I might be busy, you know. But we could--well, I got a little Vespa I just play around with.

question: Really? Why that's almost a motorcycle. And I just love motorcycles. I got to go.
answer: Ow.

question: Goodnight.
answer: See ya.

question: Yeah, who is it?
answer: It's--I want to talk to the Wolfman.

question: The Wolfman ain't here.
answer: I know, but I got to get in touch with him. I got something to give him before--

question: We don't take no deliveries after eight. Come back tomorrow.
answer: No, I can't. I want to ask him something that--

question: Dedications by phone is Diamond 75044. Wolfman Top 40 is Box 13, Chula Vista. Wolfman Sweatshirts is Wolf Enterprises, Bakersfield. 'Bye.
answer: Listen, I got a right to talk to him. I listened to him every night for as long--for twelve years almost. I know him and it's personal and it'll only take a minute and I bet Wolfman would be upset if he knew a friend couldn't get in touch with--

question: Listen, I got a right to talk to him. I listened to him every night for as long--for twelve years almost. I know him and it's personal and it'll only take a minute and I bet Wolfman would be upset if he knew a friend couldn't get in touch with--
answer: What do you want? Pull the red switch.

question: I'm looking for a girl.
answer: Aren't we all. She ain't here. Come on back to the booth. Hey, have a popsicle. The ice box just broke down and they're meltin' all over the place. You want one?

question: No. Thanks. Listen, ah...
answer: Have a popsicle.

question: Are you the Wolfman?
answer: No, man. I'm not the Wolfman.

question: Well, ah--where does he work? I mean, where is the Wolfman now?
answer: The Wolfman is everywhere.

question: But I got to give him this note.
answer: Here, let me see the note. Hell, that's just a dedication. All I gotta do is relay it. And it'll be on the air tomorrow, or Tuesday at the latest.

question: No, no. See, this is very important. I may be leaving town tomorrow, and it's very important that I--damn it, that I reach this girl right now.
answer: You don't know whether you're gonna leave town or not?

question: Well, I'm supposed to go to college back East tomorrow. And I don't know if I'm gonna go.
answer: Wait a minute. Have a popsicle.

question: No, thank you.
answer: Sit down a minute. Listen, it's early in the morning. Now, I can't really talk for the Wolfman. But I think if he was here he'd tell you to get your ass in gear. Now, no offense to your home town here, but this place ain't exactly the hub of the universe, if you know what I mean. And well--I'll tell you this much--the Wolfman does come in here now and then, with tapes, to check up on me, you know, and when I hear the stories he got about the places he goes. Hell, here I sit while there's a big beautiful world out there, don't ya know. Wolfman comes in last time talking about some exotic jungle country, handing me cigars he says was rolled on the naked thighs of brown beauties. The Wolfman been everywhere and he seen everything. He got so many stories, so many memories. And here I sit sucking on popsicles.

question: Why don't you leave?
answer: Well, I'm no kid anymore. I been here a long time. And the Wolfman-- well, the Wolfman gave me my start and he's sorta become my life. I can't leave him now. Gotta be loyal to the Wolfman, you understand. I tell you what. If I can possibly do it tonight, I'll try to relay this dedication and get it on the air for you later on.

question: That'd be great. Thanks. Really.
answer: Sorry, sticky little mothers ain't they? Bye.

question: You stupid sonofabitch, she was in that car! Why did you have--
answer: I said I didn't--you lousy greasy jerk! You coulda killed me--what's wrong with you. You clubfoot... No, no, no. Please, don't come near me. No, please. I think I'm gonna be sick. Oh, Steven.

question: Laurie, please.
answer: Oh, Steven! Oh, Steven, please, don't leave me. Don't leave me, Steven.

question: I won't.
answer: I couldn't bear it.

question: I won't.
answer: Please.

question: Come on, before she blows.
answer: Jeez, did you show him! He'll probably never even get in a car again.

question: He was faster.
answer: It was beautiful, John. Just beauti-- what?

question: I was losin', man.
answer: What?

question: He had me, man. He was pullin' away from me just before he crashed.
answer: You're crazy.

question: You saw it.
answer: No, you creamed him, from right off the line. The guy never had a chance.

question: Shit, Toad. The man had me. He was beating me.
answer: John, I don't know what you're talking about. It was the most beautiful thing I've ever seen. That guy, he might as well get a wheelchair and roll himself home. Man, you got... you got the bitchinist car in the Valley. You'll always be number one, John. You're the greatest.

question: Look at your glasses, man. Okay, Toad. We'll take 'em all.
answer: Right.

question: We'll take em... let's get out of here.
answer: Jesus, what a night.

question: Hello, hello, hello!
answer: Curt?

question: Yeah... this is Curt, who is this?
answer: Who were you expecting?

question: Do you drive a white T-Bird?
answer: A white '56. I saw you on Third Street.

question: You know me.
answer: Of course!

question: Who are you? How do you know me?
answer: It's not important.

question: It's important to me. You're the most perfect, beautiful creature I've ever seen and I don't know anything about you. Could we meet someplace?
answer: I cruise Third Street every night. Maybe I'll see you again tonight.

question: No... I don't think so.
answer: Why?

question: I'm leaving... in a couple of hours. Where are you from?
answer: Curt...

question: What's your name? At least tell me your name?
answer: Goodbye, Curt.

question: So long, guys.
answer: Well, stay cool, man.

question: Yeah.
answer: Ah--don't do anything I wouldn't do.
